title: Resistance - current with 2x radius and 2x length

content.question: Two wires, Wire <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, have circular cross sections and are made from the same material. Wire <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a cross-sectional radius <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> and length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a cross-sectional radius <math alttext="2 lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>r</mi></math> and length <math alttext="2 L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi></math>. Wires <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are connected to identical batteries and have currents <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively. What is the ratio <math alttext="I sub 2, to I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
